commit.message:
Docs: various fixes in the documentation

-- The TF-M build instructions are updated to specify
   which version of CMSIS_5 has to be used, i.e. 5.2.0.
-- The TF-M user guide is updated with the correct
   names of the files to be copied in the MPS2 board
   software folder, and some formatting issues are
   fixed.
-- Remove the --start cpu0=<addr> command in the FVP
   instruction as they are outdated and redundant.

Change-Id: I2004e6466c807a0e82e0e1f169e55061f183ad3a
Signed-off-by: Antonio de Angelis <antonio.deangelis@arm.com>

Merge the dev branch to master.

coarsen by prefix, 
un-coarsen and refinement,
 strenghten mpi-syncs,
 new software versions, 
taking updated T5 from HF after thier tiny bug fix, 
stronger baseline,
stronger mpipe, 
stronger memory limit, 
mps, 
Added some experiments according to reviewer's requests.
refactoring.

mixed-precision,
fine-tuning with quantization,
enhance profiling with optimizer.step(), staleness mitigation, and maybe lower level ops
code cleanup
combination with hetrogenous (devices/network), data-parallelism, ...
heuristics and partitioning for inference 
support other frameworks (tf, onnx, ...)

Add and document important open-problems and add ommited paper parts so future research can further advance.

repository.name: FTPipe
repository.description: FTPipe and related pipeline model parallelism research.

#### Others


[#​12221](https://togithub.com/aquaproj/aqua-registry/issues/12221)
Introduced
[aqua-registry-updater](https://togithub.com/aquaproj/aqua-registry-updater)
instead of Renovate to update packages continuously

aqua-registry has too many aqua packages for Whitesource Renovate to
work well.
We tuned Renovate configuration, but we couldn't solve the issue
completely.
Renovate called many GitHub API unnecessarily.
We thought it was difficult to solve the issue by Renovate because

-   Renovate was complicated
-   Renovate's specification was unclear
-   Renovate outputted many logs so it was bothersome to read logs
-   Renovate log wasn't so helpful to solve the issue at this time
- The issue was an edge case for Renovate, so the same issue wouldn't
occur in others. So we couldn't expect Renovate was updated to solve the
issue

And we thought it wasn't so difficult to develop a tool to update aqua
packages, so we decided to develop aqua-registry-updater instead of
Renovate.

aqua-registry-updater works well and solves the issue.

#### :warning: Breaking Changes


[#​11836](https://togithub.com/aquaproj/aqua-registry/issues/11836)
Change the checksum file_format to the default format

aqua >= ~~v1.37.0~~ v2.4.2 is required.

About the default format, please see the following links.

-
[https://github.com/aquaproj/aqua/pull/1577#issue-1551717692](https://togithub.com/aquaproj/aqua/pull/1577#issue-1551717692)
-
[https://github.com/aquaproj/aqua/pull/1762](https://togithub.com/aquaproj/aqua/pull/1762)

##### How to migrate

If you enable the checksum verification, please upgrade aqua to
~~v1.37.0~~ v2.4.2 or later.
If you disable checksum verification (by default, the checksum
verification is disabled), there is no problem.

When you contribute to this repository, please use aqua >=
[v2.4.2](https://togithub.com/aquaproj/aqua/releases/tag/v2.4.2).
[https://github.com/aquaproj/aqua/pull/1914](https://togithub.com/aquaproj/aqua/pull/1914)

Unfortunately, aqua < v2.4.2 has a bug of the default checksum parser,
so aqua >= v2.4.2 is required.

-   https://github.com/aquaproj/aqua/releases/tag/v2.4.2
-
[https://github.com/aquaproj/aqua/issues/1956](https://togithub.com/aquaproj/aqua/issues/1956)

</details>

Switch to autotools (GNU build system)

This commit probably comes as a surprise to some, given that one of i3’s
explicitly stated goals used to be “Do not use programs such as
autoconf/automake for configuration and creating unreadable/broken makefiles”.

I phrased this goal over 7 years ago, based largely on a grudge that I
inherited, which — as I’ve realized in the meantime — was largely held against
FOSS in general, and not actually nuanced criticism of autotools.

In the meantime, I have come to realize that the knee-jerk reaction of “I could
do this better!” (i.e. writing our own build system in this particular case) is
usually misguided, and nowadays I strongly suggest trying hard to fix the
existing system for the benefit of all existing and future users.

Further, I recently got to experience the other side of the coin, as I packaged
a new version of FreeRADIUS for Debian, which at the time of writing used
autoconf in combination with boilermake, a custom make-based build system that
only FreeRADIUS uses. Understanding the build system enough to fix issues and
enable parallel compilation took me an entire day. That time is time which
potentially every downstream maintainer needs to invest, and the resulting
knowledge cannot be applied to any other project.

Hence, I believe it’s a good idea switch i3 to autotools. Yes, it might be that
particular features were easier to implement/understand in our custom
Makefiles, and there might be individuals who have an easier time reading
through our custom Makefiles than learning autotools. All of these
considerations are outweighed by the benefits we get from using the same build
system as literally thousands of other FOSS software packages.

Aside from these somewhat philosophical considerations, there’s also practical
improvements which this change brings us. See the “changes” section below.

┌──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┐
│ new workflow                                                                 │
└──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┘

You can now build i3 like you build any other software package which uses
autotools. Here’s a memory refresher:

    autoreconf -fi
    mkdir -p build && cd build
    ../configure
    make -j8

(The autoreconf -fi step is unnecessary if you are building from a release
 tarball, but shouldn’t hurt either.)

┌──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┐
│ recommended reading                                                          │
└──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┘

I very much recommend reading “A Practitioner's Guide to GNU Autoconf,
Automake, and Libtool” by John Calcote (https://www.nostarch.com/autotools.htm).
That book is from 2010 and, AFAICT, is the most up to date comprehensive
description of autotools. Do not read older documentation. In particular, if a
document you’re reading mentions configure.in (deprecated filename) or
recursive make (now considered harmful), it’s likely outdated.

┌──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┐
│ changes                                                                      │
└──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┘

This commit implements the following new functionality/changes in behavior:

• We use the AX_ENABLE_BUILDDIR macro to enforce builds happening in a separate
  directory. This is a prerequisite for the AX_EXTEND_SRCDIR macro and building
  in a separate directory is common practice anyway. In case this causes any
  trouble when packaging i3 for your distribution, please let me know.

• “make check” runs the i3 testsuite.
  You can still use ./testcases/complete-run.pl to get the interactive progress
  output.

• “make distcheck” (runs testsuite on “make dist” result, tiny bit quicker
  feedback cycle than waiting for the travis build to catch the issue).

• “make uninstall” (occasionally requested by users who compile from source)

• “make” will build manpages/docs by default if the tools are installed.
  Conversely, manpages/docs are not tried to be built for users who don’t want
  to install all these dependencies to get started hacking on i3.

• non-release builds will enable address sanitizer by default. Use the
  --disable-sanitizers configure option to turn off all sanitizers, and see
  --help for available sanitizers.

• Support for pre-compiled headers (PCH) has been dropped for now in the
  interest of simplicitly. Maybe we can re-add it later.

• coverage reports are now generated using “make check-code-coverage”, which
  requires specifying --enable-code-coverage when calling configure.

┌──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┐
│ build system feature parity/testing                                          │
└──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┘

In addition to what’s described above, I tested the following features:

• “make install” installs the same files (plus documentation and manpages)
  cd i3-old && make install PREFIX=/tmp/inst/old
  cd i3-new && ./configure --prefix=/tmp/inst/new
  cd /tmp/inst
  (cd old && for f in $(find); do [ -e "../new/$f" ] || echo "$f missing"; done)

• make dist generates a tarball which includes the same files
  cd i3-old && make dist
  cd i3-new/x86_64-pc-linux-gnu && make dist
  colordiff -u <(tar tf i3-old/i3-4.12.tar.bz2 | sort) \
               <(tar tf i3-new/x86_64-pc-linux-gnu/i3-4.12.tar.gz | sort)
  There are some expected differences:
  • Some files have been renamed (e.g. the new etc/ and share/ subdirectories)
  • Some files will now be generated at build-time, so only their corresponding
    .in file is shipped (e.g. testcases/complete-run.pl)
  • The generated parser files are shipped in the dist tarball (they only
    depend on the parser-specs/* files, not on the target system)
  • autotools infrastructure is shipped (e.g. “configure”, “missing”, etc.)

• DLOG and ELOG statements still produce the same file name in logfiles

• Listing source code in gdb still works.

• gdb backtraces contain the i3-<version> path component

• release.sh still works

• version embedding
  1. git checkout shows “4.12-136-gf720023 (2016-10-10, branch "autotools")”
  2. tarball of a git version shows “4.12-non-git”
  3. release tarball shows 4.13

• debug mode is enabled by default for non-release builds

• enabling verbose builds via V=1

┌──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┐
│ speed                                                                        │
└──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┘

There is no noticeable difference in compilation speed itself (of binaries,
documentation and manpages):

i3-old $ time make all docs mans -j8
make all docs mans -j8  28.92s user 2.15s system 640% cpu 4.852 total

i3-new $ time make -j8
make -j8  27.08s user 1.92s system 620% cpu 4.669 total

In terms of one-time costs:
configuring the build system (../configure) takes about 2.7s on my machine,
generating the build system (autoreconf -fi) takes about 3.1s on my machine.

┌──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┐
│ m4 macros                                                                    │
└──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┘

All files in m4/ have been copied from the autoconf-archive package in version
b6aeb1988f4b6c78bf39d97b6c4f6e1d594d59b9 and should be updated whenever they
change.

This commit has been tested with autoconf 2.69 and automake 1.15.

(The autoreconf -fi step is unnecessary if you are building from a release
 tarball, but shouldn’t hurt either.)

┌──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┐
│ recommended reading                                                          │
└──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┘

I very much recommend reading “A Practitioner's Guide to GNU Autoconf,
Automake, and Libtool” by John Calcote (https://www.nostarch.com/autotools.htm).
That book is from 2010 and, AFAICT, is the most up to date comprehensive
description of autotools. Do not read older documentation. In particular, if a
document you’re reading mentions configure.in (deprecated filename) or
recursive make (now considered harmful), it’s likely outdated.

┌──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┐
│ changes                                                                      │
└──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┘

This commit implements the following new functionality/changes in behavior:

• We use the AX_ENABLE_BUILDDIR macro to enforce builds happening in a separate
  directory. This is a prerequisite for the AX_EXTEND_SRCDIR macro and building
  in a separate directory is common practice anyway. In case this causes any
  trouble when packaging i3 for your distribution, please let me know.

• “make check” runs the i3 testsuite.
  You can still use ./testcases/complete-run.pl to get the interactive progress
  output.

• “make distcheck” (runs testsuite on “make dist” result, tiny bit quicker
  feedback cycle than waiting for the travis build to catch the issue).

• “make uninstall” (occasionally requested by users who compile from source)

• “make” will build manpages/docs by default if the tools are installed.
  Conversely, manpages/docs are not tried to be built for users who don’t want
  to install all these dependencies to get started hacking on i3.

• non-release builds will enable address sanitizer by default. Use the
  --disable-sanitizers configure option to turn off all sanitizers, and see
  --help for available sanitizers.

• Support for pre-compiled headers (PCH) has been dropped for now in the
  interest of simplicitly. Maybe we can re-add it later.

• coverage reports are now generated using “make check-code-coverage”, which
  requires specifying --enable-code-coverage when calling configure.

┌──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┐
│ build system feature parity/testing                                          │
└──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┘

In addition to what’s described above, I tested the following features:

• “make install” installs the same files (plus documentation and manpages)
  cd i3-old && make install PREFIX=/tmp/inst/old
  cd i3-new && ./configure --prefix=/tmp/inst/new
  cd /tmp/inst
  (cd old && for f in $(find); do [ -e "../new/$f" ] || echo "$f missing"; done)

• make dist generates a tarball which includes the same files
  cd i3-old && make dist
  cd i3-new/x86_64-pc-linux-gnu && make dist
  colordiff -u <(tar tf i3-old/i3-4.12.tar.bz2 | sort) \
               <(tar tf i3-new/x86_64-pc-linux-gnu/i3-4.12.tar.gz | sort)
  There are some expected differences:
  • Some files have been renamed (e.g. the new etc/ and share/ subdirectories)
  • Some files will now be generated at build-time, so only their corresponding
    .in file is shipped (e.g. testcases/complete-run.pl)
  • The generated parser files are shipped in the dist tarball (they only
    depend on the parser-specs/* files, not on the target system)
  • autotools infrastructure is shipped (e.g. “configure”, “missing”, etc.)

• DLOG and ELOG statements still produce the same file name in logfiles

• Listing source code in gdb still works.

• gdb backtraces contain the i3-<version> path component

• release.sh still works

• version embedding
  1. git checkout shows “4.12-136-gf720023 (2016-10-10, branch "autotools")”
  2. tarball of a git version shows “4.12-non-git”
  3. release tarball shows 4.13

• debug mode is enabled by default for non-release builds

• enabling verbose builds via V=1

┌──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┐
│ speed                                                                        │
└──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┘

There is no noticeable difference in compilation speed itself (of binaries,
documentation and manpages):

i3-old $ time make all docs mans -j8
make all docs mans -j8  28.92s user 2.15s system 640% cpu 4.852 total

i3-new $ time make -j8
make -j8  27.08s user 1.92s system 620% cpu 4.669 total

In terms of one-time costs:
configuring the build system (../configure) takes about 2.7s on my machine,
generating the build system (autoreconf -fi) takes about 3.1s on my machine.

┌──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┐
│ m4 macros                                                                    │
└──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┘

All files in m4/ have been copied from the autoconf-archive package in version
b6aeb1988f4b6c78bf39d97b6c4f6e1d594d59b9 and should be updated whenever they
change.

This commit has been tested with autoconf 2.69 and automake 1.15.

commit.message:
Switch to autotools (GNU build system)

This commit probably comes as a surprise to some, given that one of i3’s
explicitly stated goals used to be “Do not use programs such as
autoconf/automake for configuration and creating unreadable/broken makefiles”.

I phrased this goal over 7 years ago, based largely on a grudge that I
inherited, which — as I’ve realized in the meantime — was largely held against
FOSS in general, and not actually nuanced criticism of autotools.

In the meantime, I have come to realize that the knee-jerk reaction of “I could
do this better!” (i.e. writing our own build system in this particular case) is
usually misguided, and nowadays I strongly suggest trying hard to fix the
existing system for the benefit of all existing and future users.

Further, I recently got to experience the other side of the coin, as I packaged
a new version of FreeRADIUS for Debian, which at the time of writing used
autoconf in combination with boilermake, a custom make-based build system that
only FreeRADIUS uses. Understanding the build system enough to fix issues and
enable parallel compilation took me an entire day. That time is time which
potentially every downstream maintainer needs to invest, and the resulting
knowledge cannot be applied to any other project.

Hence, I believe it’s a good idea switch i3 to autotools. Yes, it might be that
particular features were easier to implement/understand in our custom
Makefiles, and there might be individuals who have an easier time reading
through our custom Makefiles than learning autotools. All of these
considerations are outweighed by the benefits we get from using the same build
system as literally thousands of other FOSS software packages.

Aside from these somewhat philosophical considerations, there’s also practical
improvements which this change brings us. See the “changes” section below.

┌──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┐
│ new workflow                                                                 │
└──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┘

You can now build i3 like you build any other software package which uses
autotools. Here’s a memory refresher:

    autoreconf -fi
    mkdir -p build && cd build
    ../configure
    make -j8

(The autoreconf -fi step is unnecessary if you are building from a release
 tarball, but shouldn’t hurt either.)

  to install all these dependencies to get started hacking on i3.

system as literally thousands of other FOSS software packages.

Aside from these somewhat philosophical considerations, there’s also practical
improvements which this change brings us. See the “changes” section below.

┌──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┐
│ new workflow                                                                 │
└──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┘

You can now build i3 like you build any other software package which uses
autotools. Here’s a memory refresher:

    autoreconf -fi
    mkdir -p build && cd build
    ../configure
    make -j8

(The autoreconf -fi step is unnecessary if you are building from a release
 tarball, but shouldn’t hurt either.)

┌──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┐
│ recommended reading                                                          │
└──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┘

I very much recommend reading “A Practitioner's Guide to GNU Autoconf,
Automake, and Libtool” by John Calcote (https://www.nostarch.com/autotools.htm).
That book is from 2010 and, AFAICT, is the most up to date comprehensive
description of autotools. Do not read older documentation. In particular, if a
document you’re reading mentions configure.in (deprecated filename) or
recursive make (now considered harmful), it’s likely outdated.

┌──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┐
│ changes                                                                      │
└──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┘

This commit implements the following new functionality/changes in behavior:

• We use the AX_ENABLE_BUILDDIR macro to enforce builds happening in a separate
  directory. This is a prerequisite for the AX_EXTEND_SRCDIR macro and building
  in a separate directory is common practice anyway. In case this causes any
  trouble when packaging i3 for your distribution, please let me know.

• “make check” runs the i3 testsuite.
  You can still use ./testcases/complete-run.pl to get the interactive progress
  output.

• “make distcheck” (runs testsuite on “make dist” result, tiny bit quicker
  feedback cycle than waiting for the travis build to catch the issue).

• “make uninstall” (occasionally requested by users who compile from source)

• “make” will build manpages/docs by default if the tools are installed.
  Conversely, manpages/docs are not tried to be built for users who don’t want
  to install all these dependencies to get started hacking on i3.

• non-release builds will enable address sanitizer by default. Use the
  --disable-sanitizers configure option to turn off all sanitizers, and see
  --help for available sanitizers.

• Support for pre-compiled headers (PCH) has been dropped for now in the
  interest of simplicitly. Maybe we can re-add it later.

• coverage reports are now generated using “make check-code-coverage”, which
  requires specifying --enable-code-coverage when calling configure.

┌──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┐
│ build system feature parity/testing                                          │
└──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┘

In addition to what’s described above, I tested the following features:

• “make install” installs the same files (plus documentation and manpages)
  cd i3-old && make install PREFIX=/tmp/inst/old
  cd i3-new && ./configure --prefix=/tmp/inst/new
  cd /tmp/inst
  (cd old && for f in $(find); do [ -e "../new/$f" ] || echo "$f missing"; done)

• make dist generates a tarball which includes the same files
  cd i3-old && make dist
  cd i3-new/x86_64-pc-linux-gnu && make dist
  colordiff -u <(tar tf i3-old/i3-4.12.tar.bz2 | sort) \
               <(tar tf i3-new/x86_64-pc-linux-gnu/i3-4.12.tar.gz | sort)
  There are some expected differences:
  • Some files have been renamed (e.g. the new etc/ and share/ subdirectories)
  • Some files will now be generated at build-time, so only their corresponding
    .in file is shipped (e.g. testcases/complete-run.pl)
  • The generated parser files are shipped in the dist tarball (they only
    depend on the parser-specs/* files, not on the target system)
  • autotools infrastructure is shipped (e.g. “configure”, “missing”, etc.)

• DLOG and ELOG statements still produce the same file name in logfiles

• Listing source code in gdb still works.

• gdb backtraces contain the i3-<version> path component

• release.sh still works

• version embedding
  1. git checkout shows “4.12-136-gf720023 (2016-10-10, branch "autotools")”
  2. tarball of a git version shows “4.12-non-git”
  3. release tarball shows 4.13

• debug mode is enabled by default for non-release builds

• enabling verbose builds via V=1

┌──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┐
│ speed                                                                        │
└──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┘

There is no noticeable difference in compilation speed itself (of binaries,
documentation and manpages):

i3-old $ time make all docs mans -j8
make all docs mans -j8  28.92s user 2.15s system 640% cpu 4.852 total

i3-new $ time make -j8
make -j8  27.08s user 1.92s system 620% cpu 4.669 total

In terms of one-time costs:
configuring the build system (../configure) takes about 2.7s on my machine,
generating the build system (autoreconf -fi) takes about 3.1s on my machine.

┌──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┐
│ m4 macros                                                                    │
└──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┘

All files in m4/ have been copied from the autoconf-archive package in version
b6aeb1988f4b6c78bf39d97b6c4f6e1d594d59b9 and should be updated whenever they
change.

This commit has been tested with autoconf 2.69 and automake 1.15.

commit.message:
Switch to autotools (GNU build system)

This commit probably comes as a surprise to some, given that one of i3’s
explicitly stated goals used to be “Do not use programs such as
autoconf/automake for configuration and creating unreadable/broken makefiles”.

I phrased this goal over 7 years ago, based largely on a grudge that I
inherited, which — as I’ve realized in the meantime — was largely held against
FOSS in general, and not actually nuanced criticism of autotools.

In the meantime, I have come to realize that the knee-jerk reaction of “I could
do this better!” (i.e. writing our own build system in this particular case) is
usually misguided, and nowadays I strongly suggest trying hard to fix the
existing system for the benefit of all existing and future users.

Further, I recently got to experience the other side of the coin, as I packaged
a new version of FreeRADIUS for Debian, which at the time of writing used
autoconf in combination with boilermake, a custom make-based build system that
only FreeRADIUS uses. Understanding the build system enough to fix issues and
enable parallel compilation took me an entire day. That time is time which
potentially every downstream maintainer needs to invest, and the resulting
knowledge cannot be applied to any other project.

Hence, I believe it’s a good idea switch i3 to autotools. Yes, it might be that
particular features were easier to implement/understand in our custom
Makefiles, and there might be individuals who have an easier time reading
through our custom Makefiles than learning autotools. All of these
considerations are outweighed by the benefits we get from using the same build
system as literally thousands of other FOSS software packages.

Aside from these somewhat philosophical considerations, there’s also practical
improvements which this change brings us. See the “changes” section below.

existing system for the benefit of all existing and future users.

Further, I recently got to experience the other side of the coin, as I packaged
a new version of FreeRADIUS for Debian, which at the time of writing used
autoconf in combination with boilermake, a custom make-based build system that
only FreeRADIUS uses. Understanding the build system enough to fix issues and
enable parallel compilation took me an entire day. That time is time which
potentially every downstream maintainer needs to invest, and the resulting
knowledge cannot be applied to any other project.

Hence, I believe it’s a good idea switch i3 to autotools. Yes, it might be that
particular features were easier to implement/understand in our custom
Makefiles, and there might be individuals who have an easier time reading
through our custom Makefiles than learning autotools. All of these
considerations are outweighed by the benefits we get from using the same build
system as literally thousands of other FOSS software packages.

Aside from these somewhat philosophical considerations, there’s also practical
improvements which this change brings us. See the “changes” section below.

┌──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┐
│ new workflow                                                                 │
└──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┘

You can now build i3 like you build any other software package which uses
autotools. Here’s a memory refresher:

    autoreconf -fi
    mkdir -p build && cd build
    ../configure
    make -j8

(The autoreconf -fi step is unnecessary if you are building from a release
 tarball, but shouldn’t hurt either.)

┌──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┐
│ recommended reading                                                          │
└──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┘

I very much recommend reading “A Practitioner's Guide to GNU Autoconf,
Automake, and Libtool” by John Calcote (https://www.nostarch.com/autotools.htm).
That book is from 2010 and, AFAICT, is the most up to date comprehensive
description of autotools. Do not read older documentation. In particular, if a
document you’re reading mentions configure.in (deprecated filename) or
recursive make (now considered harmful), it’s likely outdated.

┌──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┐
│ changes                                                                      │
└──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┘

This commit implements the following new functionality/changes in behavior:

• We use the AX_ENABLE_BUILDDIR macro to enforce builds happening in a separate
  directory. This is a prerequisite for the AX_EXTEND_SRCDIR macro and building
  in a separate directory is common practice anyway. In case this causes any
  trouble when packaging i3 for your distribution, please let me know.

• “make check” runs the i3 testsuite.
  You can still use ./testcases/complete-run.pl to get the interactive progress
  output.

• “make distcheck” (runs testsuite on “make dist” result, tiny bit quicker
  feedback cycle than waiting for the travis build to catch the issue).

• “make uninstall” (occasionally requested by users who compile from source)

• “make” will build manpages/docs by default if the tools are installed.
  Conversely, manpages/docs are not tried to be built for users who don’t want
  to install all these dependencies to get started hacking on i3.

• non-release builds will enable address sanitizer by default. Use the
  --disable-sanitizers configure option to turn off all sanitizers, and see
  --help for available sanitizers.

• Support for pre-compiled headers (PCH) has been dropped for now in the
  interest of simplicitly. Maybe we can re-add it later.

• coverage reports are now generated using “make check-code-coverage”, which
  requires specifying --enable-code-coverage when calling configure.

┌──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┐
│ build system feature parity/testing                                          │
└──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┘

In addition to what’s described above, I tested the following features:

• “make install” installs the same files (plus documentation and manpages)
  cd i3-old && make install PREFIX=/tmp/inst/old
  cd i3-new && ./configure --prefix=/tmp/inst/new
  cd /tmp/inst
  (cd old && for f in $(find); do [ -e "../new/$f" ] || echo "$f missing"; done)

• make dist generates a tarball which includes the same files
  cd i3-old && make dist
  cd i3-new/x86_64-pc-linux-gnu && make dist
  colordiff -u <(tar tf i3-old/i3-4.12.tar.bz2 | sort) \
               <(tar tf i3-new/x86_64-pc-linux-gnu/i3-4.12.tar.gz | sort)
  There are some expected differences:
  • Some files have been renamed (e.g. the new etc/ and share/ subdirectories)
  • Some files will now be generated at build-time, so only their corresponding
    .in file is shipped (e.g. testcases/complete-run.pl)
  • The generated parser files are shipped in the dist tarball (they only
    depend on the parser-specs/* files, not on the target system)
  • autotools infrastructure is shipped (e.g. “configure”, “missing”, etc.)

• DLOG and ELOG statements still produce the same file name in logfiles

• Listing source code in gdb still works.

• gdb backtraces contain the i3-<version> path component

• release.sh still works

• version embedding
  1. git checkout shows “4.12-136-gf720023 (2016-10-10, branch "autotools")”
  2. tarball of a git version shows “4.12-non-git”
  3. release tarball shows 4.13

• debug mode is enabled by default for non-release builds

• enabling verbose builds via V=1

┌──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┐
│ speed                                                                        │
└──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┘

There is no noticeable difference in compilation speed itself (of binaries,
documentation and manpages):

i3-old $ time make all docs mans -j8
make all docs mans -j8  28.92s user 2.15s system 640% cpu 4.852 total

i3-new $ time make -j8
make -j8  27.08s user 1.92s system 620% cpu 4.669 total

In terms of one-time costs:
configuring the build system (../configure) takes about 2.7s on my machine,
generating the build system (autoreconf -fi) takes about 3.1s on my machine.

┌──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┐
│ m4 macros                                                                    │
└──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┘

All files in m4/ have been copied from the autoconf-archive package in version
b6aeb1988f4b6c78bf39d97b6c4f6e1d594d59b9 and should be updated whenever they
change.

This commit has been tested with autoconf 2.69 and automake 1.15.

commit.message:
Switch to autotools (GNU build system)

This commit probably comes as a surprise to some, given that one of i3’s
explicitly stated goals used to be “Do not use programs such as
autoconf/automake for configuration and creating unreadable/broken makefiles”.

I phrased this goal over 7 years ago, based largely on a grudge that I
inherited, which — as I’ve realized in the meantime — was largely held against
FOSS in general, and not actually nuanced criticism of autotools.

In the meantime, I have come to realize that the knee-jerk reaction of “I could
do this better!” (i.e. writing our own build system in this particular case) is
usually misguided, and nowadays I strongly suggest trying hard to fix the
existing system for the benefit of all existing and future users.

Further, I recently got to experience the other side of the coin, as I packaged
a new version of FreeRADIUS for Debian, which at the time of writing used
autoconf in combination with boilermake, a custom make-based build system that
only FreeRADIUS uses. Understanding the build system enough to fix issues and
enable parallel compilation took me an entire day. That time is time which
potentially every downstream maintainer needs to invest, and the resulting
knowledge cannot be applied to any other project.

Hence, I believe it’s a good idea switch i3 to autotools. Yes, it might be that
particular features were easier to implement/understand in our custom
Makefiles, and there might be individuals who have an easier time reading
through our custom Makefiles than learning autotools. All of these
considerations are outweighed by the benefits we get from using the same build
system as literally thousands of other FOSS software packages.

Aside from these somewhat philosophical considerations, there’s also practical
improvements which this change brings us. See the “changes” section below.

┌──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┐
│ new workflow                                                                 │
└──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┘

You can now build i3 like you build any other software package which uses
autotools. Here’s a memory refresher:

    autoreconf -fi
    mkdir -p build && cd build
    ../configure
    make -j8

(The autoreconf -fi step is unnecessary if you are building from a release
 tarball, but shouldn’t hurt either.)

┌──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┐
│ recommended reading                                                          │
└──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┘

I very much recommend reading “A Practitioner's Guide to GNU Autoconf,
Automake, and Libtool” by John Calcote (https://www.nostarch.com/autotools.htm).
That book is from 2010 and, AFAICT, is the most up to date comprehensive
description of autotools. Do not read older documentation. In particular, if a
document you’re reading mentions configure.in (deprecated filename) or
recursive make (now considered harmful), it’s likely outdated.

┌──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┐
│ changes                                                                      │
└──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┘

This commit implements the following new functionality/changes in behavior:

• We use the AX_ENABLE_BUILDDIR macro to enforce builds happening in a separate
  directory. This is a prerequisite for the AX_EXTEND_SRCDIR macro and building
  in a separate directory is common practice anyway. In case this causes any
  trouble when packaging i3 for your distribution, please let me know.

• “make check” runs the i3 testsuite.
  You can still use ./testcases/complete-run.pl to get the interactive progress
  output.

• “make distcheck” (runs testsuite on “make dist” result, tiny bit quicker
  feedback cycle than waiting for the travis build to catch the issue).

• “make uninstall” (occasionally requested by users who compile from source)

• “make” will build manpages/docs by default if the tools are installed.
  Conversely, manpages/docs are not tried to be built for users who don’t want
  to install all these dependencies to get started hacking on i3.

• non-release builds will enable address sanitizer by default. Use the
  --disable-sanitizers configure option to turn off all sanitizers, and see
  --help for available sanitizers.

• Support for pre-compiled headers (PCH) has been dropped for now in the
  interest of simplicitly. Maybe we can re-add it later.

• coverage reports are now generated using “make check-code-coverage”, which
  requires specifying --enable-code-coverage when calling configure.

┌──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┐
│ build system feature parity/testing                                          │
└──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┘

In addition to what’s described above, I tested the following features:

• “make install” installs the same files (plus documentation and manpages)
  cd i3-old && make install PREFIX=/tmp/inst/old
  cd i3-new && ./configure --prefix=/tmp/inst/new
  cd /tmp/inst
  (cd old && for f in $(find); do [ -e "../new/$f" ] || echo "$f missing"; done)

• make dist generates a tarball which includes the same files
  cd i3-old && make dist
  cd i3-new/x86_64-pc-linux-gnu && make dist
  colordiff -u <(tar tf i3-old/i3-4.12.tar.bz2 | sort) \
               <(tar tf i3-new/x86_64-pc-linux-gnu/i3-4.12.tar.gz | sort)
  There are some expected differences:
  • Some files have been renamed (e.g. the new etc/ and share/ subdirectories)
  • Some files will now be generated at build-time, so only their corresponding
    .in file is shipped (e.g. testcases/complete-run.pl)
  • The generated parser files are shipped in the dist tarball (they only
    depend on the parser-specs/* files, not on the target system)
  • autotools infrastructure is shipped (e.g. “configure”, “missing”, etc.)

• DLOG and ELOG statements still produce the same file name in logfiles

• Listing source code in gdb still works.

• gdb backtraces contain the i3-<version> path component

• release.sh still works

• version embedding
  1. git checkout shows “4.12-136-gf720023 (2016-10-10, branch "autotools")”
  2. tarball of a git version shows “4.12-non-git”
  3. release tarball shows 4.13

• debug mode is enabled by default for non-release builds

• enabling verbose builds via V=1

┌──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┐
│ speed                                                                        │
└──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┘

There is no noticeable difference in compilation speed itself (of binaries,
documentation and manpages):

i3-old $ time make all docs mans -j8
make all docs mans -j8  28.92s user 2.15s system 640% cpu 4.852 total

i3-new $ time make -j8
make -j8  27.08s user 1.92s system 620% cpu 4.669 total

In terms of one-time costs:
configuring the build system (../configure) takes about 2.7s on my machine,
generating the build system (autoreconf -fi) takes about 3.1s on my machine.

┌──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┐
│ m4 macros                                                                    │
└──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┘

All files in m4/ have been copied from the autoconf-archive package in version
b6aeb1988f4b6c78bf39d97b6c4f6e1d594d59b9 and should be updated whenever they
change.

This commit has been tested with autoconf 2.69 and automake 1.15.

* May have fixed convergence issue by cranking up z gain, will have to look at convergence properties in the future?

* Fix message timing bugs in inverse_dynamics.cpp and correct spirit_utils CMakeLists to declare catkin package dependencies

* Merging with Joe's commit

* Bug fixes on MPC

* Added normal force constraint in friction cone form

* Start custom message interpolation

* MPC fix with numerical stability

* Translation working perfectly using world velocity, will need to switch to body velocity

* Add msg interp functions and mocap optitrack

* update test_fast_terrain_map.cpp

* Pre-swapping traj publisher contents from vectors to messages

* Issue is in Matlab derivation of jacobian, will update with fix

* Finish message based trajectory interpolation

* Remove commented code

* Add trajectory topic to params yaml

* add debug to traj pub

* MPC++ partially updated with orientation

* Orientation added to MPC formulation

* Debugging orientation, getting single step latency when passing in zero cartesian references and orientation

* Added launch files to run planner in gazebo

* Debugged orientation component of MPC (not modifying first element of Bd)

* Add flag to only update trajectory when we have new information

* reset project_params.yaml

* Fixed typo in header file

* Switch from ControlInput to GRFArray messages

* Moved dynamics inside class, renamed class to QuadrupedalMPC and doxygen'd everything

* Moved mpcplusplus into mpc_controller, sent matrix_algebra and matplotlibcpp to spirit_utils

* Update colors in rviz and rviz_interface

* Remove SwingLegPlan.msg (outdated)

* Update matplotlib to be accessible through spirit_utils package

* Add consistent timing and primitive_ids to twist body planner

* Remove obstacle in internal terrain map for simpler testing, update goal state accordingly

* Update MATLAB plotting script, slow down GBP, fix interpHeader bug

* Fix bug in twist body planner from missing state data

* Add foot position and velocity to MATLAB parsing script

* Updated sdf for visuals, updating gazebo plugins, integrating ID node

* Add simultaneous state visualization to rviz

* Update spirit_logger to handle both ground_truth and trajectory data (still need to plot both simultaneously)

* Merged from nf_mpc_controller

* Remove dependency on ControlInput.msg (deprecated)

* Add joint names to gazebo estimator_plugin

* Fix error in foot plan velocity, make rviz and matlab scripts real pretty

* MPC intermittent push

* MPC conversion almost there

* MPC publishing GRFS

* Add MPC control modification to saturate at end of current plan

* Now zeroing out velocities once we reach the end of our planner

* MPC incremental updates, createing custom launch file for MPC gazebo testing

* Fixed linear constraint update problem

* Ready for inverse dynamics integration

* Suppressing control mode warning in inverse dynamics

* MPC nominal improvement

* Added hip projection MPC mode

* Move message helper functions to ros_utils, add source code for ros_utils, update fkRobotState and ikRobotState to take kinematics object handle as arg

* Adding twist keyboard planner

* Adding key controller to nf mpc controller

* Fixed directionality of angular velocity in twist controller

Co-authored-by: jcnorby <jnorby@andrew.cmu.edu>
Co-authored-by: Joe Norby <jcnorby@gmail.com>
Co-authored-by: Nathan Kong <njkong@andrew.cmu.edu>
Co-authored-by: Mike Turski <mturski@andrew.cmu.edu>

* Remove SwingLegPlan.msg (outdated)

* Add consistent timing and primitive_ids to twist body planner

* Update MATLAB plotting script, slow down GBP, fix interpHeader bug

* Fix bug in twist body planner from missing state data

* Add foot position and velocity to MATLAB parsing script

* Updated sdf for visuals, updating gazebo plugins, integrating ID node

* Add simultaneous state visualization to rviz

* Update spirit_logger to handle both ground_truth and trajectory data (still need to plot both simultaneously)

* Merged from nf_mpc_controller

* Remove dependency on ControlInput.msg (deprecated)

* Add joint names to gazebo estimator_plugin

* Fix error in foot plan velocity, make rviz and matlab scripts real pretty

* MPC intermittent push

* MPC conversion almost there

* MPC publishing GRFS

* Add MPC control modification to saturate at end of current plan

* Now zeroing out velocities once we reach the end of our planner

* MPC incremental updates, createing custom launch file for MPC gazebo testing

* Fixed linear constraint update problem

* Ready for inverse dynamics integration

* Suppressing control mode warning in inverse dynamics

* MPC nominal improvement

* Added hip projection MPC mode

* Move message helper functions to ros_utils, add source code for ros_utils, update fkRobotState and ikRobotState to take kinematics object handle as arg

* Adding twist keyboard planner

* Adding key controller to nf mpc controller

* Fixed directionality of angular velocity in twist controller

* started inverse dynamics node. Need to make sure we add the right messages and ros topics

* Specializing mpc++, too much overhead to maintain generality

* Add base class for trajectory publisher, swing leg parsing not done yet

* Add some more detail to traj pub, start setting up LFP for replanning

* Added contact constraints

* Initial commit with changed foot plan messages, started reworking LFP

* New foot plan messages work, trajectory publisher currently untested

* Trajectory publisher works, still a bug in the global plan somewhere

* Fix bug caused by out-of-date tf and jointstate messages (update timestamp in rviz_interface)

* Fix bug in trajectory publisher (forgot to clear old data in callbacks)

* Remove debug statement

* update kinematics to reflect urdf

* pushing skeleton inverse dynamics node

* Update footstep message in mpc-controller

* Update rviz colors

* Fixed motor command and swapped it to leg command array

* Fix merge bug in LFP

* Add body-foot FK to SpiritKinematics

* Remove body variables in body-foot FK

* MPC progress

* MPCPlusPlus dimensionality working for legged robots

* Switch pitch from planned state to terrain defined, update spirit parameters (width was far too narrow)

* Update robot state initialization in GBP

* Fix bug in handling initial and final footstep locations

* Revert to yielding knee-above-toe solutions for IK

* Updated spirit utils cmake list to allow including eigen

* Switch to terrain-based height, add filtered layers to terrain maps

* add primitive to body plan, switch from wrench to grf

* Updated stuff

* Working MPC with friction cone

* Small bug fixes

* Updated normal force bounds, getting better results

* Need to rework dynamics constraint

* Debugging friction cone

* Identified weird error with osqp-eigen bounds

* Adding standing control with foot jacobains (in progress)

* May have fixed convergence issue by cranking up z gain, will have to look at convergence properties in the future?

* Fix message timing bugs in inverse_dynamics.cpp and correct spirit_utils CMakeLists to declare catkin package dependencies

* Merging with Joe's commit

* Bug fixes on MPC

* Added normal force constraint in friction cone form

* Start custom message interpolation

* MPC fix with numerical stability

* Translation working perfectly using world velocity, will need to switch to body velocity

* Add msg interp functions and mocap optitrack

* update test_fast_terrain_map.cpp

* Pre-swapping traj publisher contents from vectors to messages

* Issue is in Matlab derivation of jacobian, will update with fix

* Finish message based trajectory interpolation

* Remove commented code

* Add trajectory topic to params yaml

* add debug to traj pub

* MPC++ partially updated with orientation

* Orientation added to MPC formulation

* Debugging orientation, getting single step latency when passing in zero cartesian references and orientation

* Added launch files to run planner in gazebo

* Debugged orientation component of MPC (not modifying first element of Bd)

* Add flag to only update trajectory when we have new information

* reset project_params.yaml

* Fixed typo in header file

* Switch from ControlInput to GRFArray messages

* Moved mpcplusplus into mpc_controller, sent matrix_algebra and matplotlibcpp to spirit_utils

* Update colors in rviz and rviz_interface

* Remove SwingLegPlan.msg (outdated)

* Update matplotlib to be accessible through spirit_utils package

* Add consistent timing and primitive_ids to twist body planner

* Remove obstacle in internal terrain map for simpler testing, update goal state accordingly

* Update MATLAB plotting script, slow down GBP, fix interpHeader bug

* Fix bug in twist body planner from missing state data

* Add foot position and velocity to MATLAB parsing script

* Updated sdf for visuals, updating gazebo plugins, integrating ID node

* Add simultaneous state visualization to rviz

* Update spirit_logger to handle both ground_truth and trajectory data (still need to plot both simultaneously)

* Merged from nf_mpc_controller

* Remove dependency on ControlInput.msg (deprecated)

* Add joint names to gazebo estimator_plugin

* Fix error in foot plan velocity, make rviz and matlab scripts real pretty

* MPC intermittent push

* MPC conversion almost there

* MPC publishing GRFS

* Add MPC control modification to saturate at end of current plan

* Now zeroing out velocities once we reach the end of our planner

* MPC incremental updates, createing custom launch file for MPC gazebo testing

* Fixed linear constraint update problem

* Ready for inverse dynamics integration

* Suppressing control mode warning in inverse dynamics

* MPC nominal improvement

repository.name: quad_sdk_fork
repository.description: An fork of the quad_sdk repository used for generating simulated quadruped datasets.

commit.message:
Add sparse convex QP-based MPC  (#130)

* Specify full path top top tier README

* Added external folder with libInterpolate, linked libInterpolate against spirit_utils lib

* Updated travis to build all dependencies prior to catkin_make

* Travis tweak

* Travis tweak

* Removing and readding interpolate library

* Placing libInterpolate in the correct place :'(

* Removing libInterpolate from old location

* Converted interp library to use prior version of cmake

* Update the footstep planner to include desired gait sequence, timing, and body velocity dependence

* Storing IMU and joint encoder messages

* Add FastTerrainMap and implement within global_body_planner

* Update visualization to surface not point cloud

* Removed custom interp class, changed default compiler optimization level to Release

* Incremental changes

* Update yaml and launch files

* Remove outdated ImageToGridmapDemo

* Temporarily removing arm build

* Fixed bug with incorrect array elements and now foot jacobians are eigen::Matrix. Still need to update the GRF to be matching other methods

* Flipped y and z axis (second and third row) in jacobians to match the rest of the framework. Revert here if the Jacobian signs are messed up

* MPC++ working with variable statespace form

* Adding custom constraint capability

* started inverse dynamics node. Need to make sure we add the right messages and ros topics

* Specializing mpc++, too much overhead to maintain generality

* Start custom message interpolation

* Add consistent timing and primitive_ids to twist body planner

* Update colors in rviz and rviz_interface

* Remove SwingLegPlan.msg (outdated)

* Update matplotlib to be accessible through spirit_utils package

* Add consistent timing and primitive_ids to twist body planner

* Remove obstacle in internal terrain map for simpler testing, update goal state accordingly

* Update MATLAB plotting script, slow down GBP, fix interpHeader bug

* Fix bug in twist body planner from missing state data

* Add foot position and velocity to MATLAB parsing script

* Updated sdf for visuals, updating gazebo plugins, integrating ID node

* Add simultaneous state visualization to rviz

* Update spirit_logger to handle both ground_truth and trajectory data (still need to plot both simultaneously)

* Merged from nf_mpc_controller

* Remove dependency on ControlInput.msg (deprecated)

* Add joint names to gazebo estimator_plugin

* Fix error in foot plan velocity, make rviz and matlab scripts real pretty

* Add pd controller on grfs in inverse_dynamics (untested)

* Update pd gains for grfs to be more reasonable

* Add PD to feedforward GRFs, move logging to remote_driver.launch

* Get foot positions for first robot footholds

* Working towards actually implementing momentum observer including hard-coded autogenerated dynamics (work in progress, messages not hooked up).

* Momentum observer first-try implementation. Includes hacks to read Gazebo messages from /spirit/joint_states (or the old /mcu/state/jointURDF). The three joint torques for each limb are crammed into the torque component of one wrench message for now.

* Updated Matlab autogenerated body_force_estimator_dynamics and added friction terms.

* Adding missing torque scaling and fixing mirroring kinematics.

* Momentum observer toe forces and foot jacobians.

* Momentum observer publishing effective toe reaction forces.

* Basic leg overrider created and hooked into inverse_dynamics.

* Moved leg override into inverse_dynamics instead of body_force_estimator package.

* mblink _UPST_ADDRESS to fix mblink communication issues (unavailable messages remotely, async_mav_coms gettig stopped).

Co-authored-by: Nikolai Flowers <nikolaif399@gmail.com>
Co-authored-by: jcnorby <jnorby@andrew.cmu.edu>
Co-authored-by: Joe Norby <jcnorby@gmail.com>
Co-authored-by: Justin Yim <jkyim@andrew.cmu.edu>
Co-authored-by: Nathan Kong <njkong@andrew.cmu.edu>
Co-authored-by: Mike Turski <mturski@andrew.cmu.edu>

* Momentum observer first-try implementation. Includes hacks to read Gazebo messages from /spirit/joint_states (or the old /mcu/state/jointURDF). The three joint torques for each limb are crammed into the torque component of one wrench message for now.

* Updated Matlab autogenerated body_force_estimator_dynamics and added friction terms.

* Adding missing torque scaling and fixing mirroring kinematics.

* Momentum observer toe forces and foot jacobians.

* Momentum observer publishing effective toe reaction forces.

* Basic leg overrider created and hooked into inverse_dynamics.

* Moved leg override into inverse_dynamics instead of body_force_estimator package.

* mblink _UPST_ADDRESS to fix mblink communication issues (unavailable messages remotely, async_mav_coms gettig stopped).

* Adding missing torque scaling and fixing mirroring kinematics.

* Momentum observer toe forces and foot jacobians.

commit.message:
March Milestone PR (#119)

* Specify full path top top tier README

* Added external folder with libInterpolate, linked libInterpolate against spirit_utils lib

* Updated travis to build all dependencies prior to catkin_make

* Travis tweak

* Travis tweak

* Excluding external folder from doxygen, travis tweak to determine why setup.sh is failing

* Travis tweak

* Removing and readding interpolate library

* Readding interp library

* Placing libInterpolate in the correct place :'(

* Removing libInterpolate from old location

* Converted interp library to use prior version of cmake

* Should be final build tweak for libInterp

* Update the footstep planner to include desired gait sequence, timing, and body velocity dependence

* Storing IMU and joint encoder messages

* Add FastTerrainMap and implement within global_body_planner

* Add FastTerrainMap and terrain dependence to local_footstep_planner

* Add test for FastTerrainMap

* Added FastInterpolator package under spirit_utils

* Update visualization to surface not point cloud

* Removed custom interp class, changed default compiler optimization level to Release

* Add qpOASES to external/, pull in old MPC cpp implementation

* Add basic image terrain publishing

* Incremental changes

* Add image processing utility to terrain_map_publisher

* Update yaml and launch files

* Remove outdated ImageToGridmapDemo

* Remove outdated launch and yaml files

* Reorganize global_body_planner, fix slowdown, add diagnostics capabilities

* Temporarily removing arm build

* Removed all extraneous tests from libInterpolate

* Restoring ARM build to Travis, cleaning up after Joe's beautfil software engineering skills :)

* Rename 'functions' to 'planning_utils' and add namespace protection

* Clean up code a bit, switch to const variable declarations rather than #defines

* Add Doxygen comments and more rosparams to global_body_planner

* Start updating gbp to take in start and goal states over topics/params

* Move start and goal state to rosparams

* Force ekf_estimator and robot_interface to default to unit quaternions rather than zeros

* Allow gbp to continually publish better paths, strip down to just rrt_connect (removing rrt and rrt_start_connect), simplify statistics reporting

* Only print statistics if a better path was found

* Add terrain map projection

* Add wrench data to body plan message and visualize in RViz

* Add osqp and osqp-eigen to external

* Add mpcplusplus library as submodule

* Deleting deprecated package template

* Added mpcplusplus as dependency, linking with mpc_controller now

* Updated travis to pull in submodules

* Removing mpcplusplus as it was added prematurely

* Add GRF projection to local footstep planner

* Add yaw and yaw rate filters to GBP (along with debugging plotting abilities), fix LFP grf error

* Added mpcplusplus to codebase

* Add timing to local footstep planner, updated remote and robot driver launchfiles (will be overwritten in separate PR)

* Rename robot interface to robot proxy, launch mocap with proxy

* Initial commit for defining a commited horizon for gbp

* Finish adding committed horizon to GBP

* Add replanning to gbp based on state error threshold, add delays in local footstep planner to avoid crashes if no data received

* Begin adding swing leg planner

* Updated gitignore

* Adding time varying mpc option to mpcplusplus

* Removing package template

* Trivial changes to open loop controller, should be working now

* Add swing leg planner

* Finish adding swing leg planning

* Add correct timekeeping to swing leg plans, move gait parameters to yaml file

* Add more detailed terrain maps, update model in GBP to spirit, fix zero GRF magnitude bug in LFP

* First commit adding foot jacobian calculations. Might be an issue somewhere with the actual calculation

* Fixed bug with incorrect array elements and now foot jacobians are eigen::Matrix. Still need to update the GRF to be matching other methods

* Flipped y and z axis (second and third row) in jacobians to match the rest of the framework. Revert here if the Jacobian signs are messed up

* MPC++ working with variable statespace form

* Adding custom constraint capability

* started inverse dynamics node. Need to make sure we add the right messages and ros topics

* Specializing mpc++, too much overhead to maintain generality

* Add base class for trajectory publisher, swing leg parsing not done yet

* Add some more detail to traj pub, start setting up LFP for replanning

* Added contact constraints

* Initial commit with changed foot plan messages, started reworking LFP

* New foot plan messages work, trajectory publisher currently untested

* Trajectory publisher works, still a bug in the global plan somewhere

* Fix bug caused by out-of-date tf and jointstate messages (update timestamp in rviz_interface)

* Fix bug in trajectory publisher (forgot to clear old data in callbacks)

* Remove debug statement

* update kinematics to reflect urdf

* pushing skeleton inverse dynamics node

* Update footstep message in mpc-controller

* Update rviz colors

* Fixed motor command and swapped it to leg command array

* Add updated library for tx2 (renamed from its original 'linux' title from the GR Download), compiles

* switch to Eigen::Vector3f for mblink messages, floats for kp and kd

* Update mblink converter to actually compile, add libgrmblink_linux.a back in, soften gains. Ready to test

* Fix merge bug in LFP

* Add body-foot FK to SpiritKinematics

* Remove body variables in body-foot FK

* MPC progress

* MPCPlusPlus dimensionality working for legged robots

* Switch pitch from planned state to terrain defined, update spirit parameters (width was far too narrow)

* Update robot state initialization in GBP

* Fix bug in handling initial and final footstep locations

* Revert to yielding knee-above-toe solutions for IK

* Updated spirit utils cmake list to allow including eigen

* Switch to terrain-based height, add filtered layers to terrain maps

* add primitive to body plan, switch from wrench to grf

* Updated stuff

* Working MPC with friction cone

* Small bug fixes

* Updated normal force bounds, getting better results

* Need to rework dynamics constraint

* Add publishMBLink to publish joint and imu data

* Have mblink_converter publish joint torques instead of currents

* Move joint names in mblink to private member variable

* Debugging friction cone

* Identified weird error with osqp-eigen bounds

* Adding standing control with foot jacobains (in progress)

* May have fixed convergence issue by cranking up z gain, will have to look at convergence properties in the future?

* Fix message timing bugs in inverse_dynamics.cpp and correct spirit_utils CMakeLists to declare catkin package dependencies

* Merging with Joe's commit

* Bug fixes on MPC

* Added normal force constraint in friction cone form

* Update mblink_converter to work with sdk_0_12

* Start custom message interpolation

* MPC fix with numerical stability

* Translation working perfectly using world velocity, will need to switch to body velocity

* Add msg interp functions and mocap optitrack

* update test_fast_terrain_map.cpp

* Pre-swapping traj publisher contents from vectors to messages

* Issue is in Matlab derivation of jacobian, will update with fix

* Finish message based trajectory interpolation

* Remove commented code

* Add trajectory topic to params yaml

* add debug to traj pub

* MPC++ partially updated with orientation

* Orientation added to MPC formulation

* Debugging orientation, getting single step latency when passing in zero cartesian references and orientation

* Added launch files to run planner in gazebo

* Debugged orientation component of MPC (not modifying first element of Bd)

* Add flag to only update trajectory when we have new information

* reset project_params.yaml

* Fixed typo in header file

* Switch from ControlInput to GRFArray messages

* Moved dynamics inside class, renamed class to QuadrupedalMPC and doxygen'd everything

* Moved mpcplusplus into mpc_controller, sent matrix_algebra and matplotlibcpp to spirit_utils

* Update colors in rviz and rviz_interface

* Remove SwingLegPlan.msg (outdated)

* Update matplotlib to be accessible through spirit_utils package

* Add consistent timing and primitive_ids to twist body planner

* Remove obstacle in internal terrain map for simpler testing, update goal state accordingly

* Update MATLAB plotting script, slow down GBP, fix interpHeader bug

* Fix bug in twist body planner from missing state data

* Add foot position and velocity to MATLAB parsing script

* Updated sdf for visuals, updating gazebo plugins, integrating ID node

* Add simultaneous state visualization to rviz

* Update spirit_logger to handle both ground_truth and trajectory data (still need to plot both simultaneously)

* Merged from nf_mpc_controller

* Remove dependency on ControlInput.msg (deprecated)

* Add joint names to gazebo estimator_plugin

* Fix error in foot plan velocity, make rviz and matlab scripts real pretty

* Added jacobian for foot velocity calculations

* Add pd controller on grfs in inverse_dynamics (untested)

* Update pd gains for grfs to be more reasonable

* Add PD to feedforward GRFs, move logging to remote_driver.launch

* Added jacobian calc for velocities, attempting to add foot joints to sdf

* Get foot positions for first robot footholds

* Update test_inverse_dynamics.cpp

* MPC intermittent push

* Fixed spirit init state in sdf, updated inverse_dynamics test

* Error while testing inverse_dynamics node

* MPC conversion almost there

* Fix test linking in inverse dynamics

* Fixed test issues for foot_jacobians, in process of adding FK to math_utils

* Add sit, stand, and transition modes to ID node

* MPC publishing GRFS

* update mocap_optitrack config

* Working on FK implementation

* Added FK to math_utils, added foot position estimation using FK to estimator_plugin

* Fixed indexing issue in FK function in math_utils. Results appear to be correct now

* Add FK to ground truth publisher

* Lower walking gains

* Add MPC control modification to saturate at end of current plan

* Now zeroing out velocities once we reach the end of our planner

* MPC incremental updates, createing custom launch file for MPC gazebo testing

* Fixed linear constraint update problem

* Installing Eigen prior to looking for it in osqp-eigen

* Ready for inverse dynamics integration

* Added MPC grf input into inverse dynamics, currently will only follow trajectory if both trajectory and grf messages exist

* Fixed linking error in CMakeLists and removed plots for this branch in the MPC testing

Co-authored-by: Nikolai Flowers <nikolaif399@gmail.com>

* Error while testing inverse_dynamics node

* MPC conversion almost there

* Fix test linking in inverse dynamics

* Fixed test issues for foot_jacobians, in process of adding FK to math_utils

* Add sit, stand, and transition modes to ID node

* MPC publishing GRFS

* update mocap_optitrack config

* Working on FK implementation

* Added FK to math_utils, added foot position estimation using FK to estimator_plugin

* Fixed indexing issue in FK function in math_utils. Results appear to be correct now

* Add FK to ground truth publisher

* Lower walking gains

* Add MPC control modification to saturate at end of current plan

* Now zeroing out velocities once we reach the end of our planner

* MPC incremental updates, createing custom launch file for MPC gazebo testing

* Fixed linear constraint update problem

* Installing Eigen prior to looking for it in osqp-eigen

* Ready for inverse dynamics integration

* Added MPC grf input into inverse dynamics, currently will only follow trajectory if both trajectory and grf messages exist

* Fixed linking error in CMakeLists and removed plots for this branch in the MPC testing
